newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: INSIGHT-Aussie chokes short of rally goal, again.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT-Aussie chokes short of rally goal, again.

text.p: *AUD staged a rare 1/2 cent bounce after critical $0.7305/10 support held solid, but capped by $0.7380 resistance so far
*Rally not that impressive given how oversold market is after four months of decline, and downtrend seen far from over
*Talk of stops atop $0.7380 may attract speculative bids and of at least one bank protecting knock out option at $0.7310
By 8.15 am (2215 GMT) the dollar had flagged to US$0.7345/50 from a US$0.7375 high but was at least up on Wednesday's late US$0.7325/30 -- its lowest local close since August 1995.

The scale of bids at US$0.7305/10 yesterday had confirmed that as the major level to break for bears, and incidentally encouraged rumours at least one big bank was protecting a binary option position there.

This area marks last year's intra-day low and 73 cents is a serious Fibonacci level being a 50 percent retracement of the entire uptrend from the US$0.6420 trough in 1993 to the US$0.8210 peak in December 1996.
A break below this level would suggest a 62 percent retracement was on the cards, which would take the dollar to 71 cents and see the 1995 trough of US$0.7070 tested.

On the topside the currency needed to clear resistance in the US$0.7440/7480 area to counter the immediate bearish pressure and would have to recover as far as US$0.7550 for the market to have any confidence a bottom had been found.

Such a rally looked impossible while the threat of another Reserve Bank rate cut loomed large. Some doubts had crept into other markets this weak -- largely because of the dollar's very weakness -- but the forex market was taking no chances.

Many traders had been surprised by no less than three of the past four easings and vowed not to be caught long again. They were looking for a cut either next Friday following inflation and wages data or on August 6 following the RBA board meeting.
If the bank had not moved by then, it would be hard not to conclude the easing cycle was over and the A$ should rally.

The scope for a cut seemed to have grown after U.S. consumer price data showed inflation remained subdued, thus lessening the chance of a Fed hike. RBA policy is primarily determined by domestic factors but a U.S. rise would have made a cut more difficult by pressuring the A$. -- Wayne Cole 61-2 9373 1800
